 {
    "context": "Explanation of variables in the equations.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Air System Distribution Terminals ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the list the variables used in the equations and their meanings.",
    "question": "What do the variables in the equations represent?",
    "answer": "Cp_zone = Specific heat of zone air J/kg-K; Cp_inlet = Specific heat of terminal unit inlet air J/kg-K; \omega_zone = Zone air humidity ratio kg/kg; T_zone = Zone air dry-bulb temperature °C; \omega_inlet = Terminal unit inlet air humidity ratio kg/kg; T_inlet = Terminal unit inlet air dry-bulb temperature °C; \dot Q_zone = Zone load W; \dot m = Terminal unit air mass flow rate kg/s; PsyCpAirFnW = Psychrometric function; MinAirFlowFrac = User-specified zone minimum air flow fraction; MinAirFlowTurnDownFrac = User-specified zone minimum air flow turndown fraction; \dot m_max = Terminal unit maximum air mass flow rate kg/s."

    "question": "How is the maximum air flow rate in the air loop determined?",
    "answer": "The maximum air flow rate is determined by the equation: \\( \\dot m = \\max \\left( \\dot m \\frac\\dot m_OAOAFrac \\right) \\) where \\(\\dot m_OA\\) is the zone outdoor air flow rate and \\(OAFrac\\) is the fraction of outdoor air."

    "question": "How is the maximum air flow rate adjusted during reheat mode?",

    "question": "What conditions determine the setting of the primary air flow rate?",

    "question": "What are the four inputs that can be autosized in the four pipe beam model?",
    "answer": "1) L is the total length of all beam units serving the zone in m. 2) \\dot V_SADes is the design primary supply air volume flow rate in m³/s. 3) \\dot V_CWDes is the design chilled water volume flow rate in m³/s. 4) \\dot V_HWDes is the design hot water volume flow rate in m³/s."

    "context": "Context: Adjustments in central sizing data structures for air system components after solvers run.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Air System Distribution Terminals ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Explain the adjustments made in central sizing data structures for air system components.",
    "question": "Question: What adjustments are made in central sizing data structures for air system components after the solvers run?",
    "answer": "Answer: After solvers run adjustments are made because usual methods can't account for the four pipe beam sizing. If set to VentilationRequirement the air handler is too small; if set to Sensible it's too large. Adjustments are made to the air loop sizes to match the final primary supply air flow rate size."

    "context": "Energy and mass balance equations for the DDCAV model.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Air System Distribution Terminals ->  equation.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the identify the equations used in the DDCAV model for energy and mass balance.",
    "question": "What are the energy and mass balance equations used in the DDCAV model?",
    "answer": "1) \\( \\dot Q_zone = \\dot m_c C_pc T_c + \\dot m_h C_phT_h - \\dot m_d C_pz T_z \\) 2) \\( \\dot m_d = \\dot m_c + \\dot m_h \\)"
 },
 {
    "context": "Explanation of terms in the DDCAV equations.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Air System Distribution Terminals ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the define the terms used in the DDCAV model equations.",
    "question": "What do the terms \\(\\dot Q_zone\\) \\(C_pz\\) \\(C_pc\\) \\(C_ph\\) \\(T_z\\) \\(T_c\\) \\(T_h\\) \\(\\dot m_d\\) \\(\\dot m_c\\) and \\(\\dot m_h\\) represent in the DDCAV model?",
    "answer": "\\(\\dot Q_zone\\) is the zone load in W \\(C_pz\\) is the specific heat of zone air in J/kg-K \\(C_pc\\) is the specific heat of cold deck air in J/kg-K \\(C_ph\\) is the specific heat of hot deck air in J/kg-K \\(T_z\\) is the zone air dry-bulb temperature in °C \\(T_c\\) is the cold deck air dry-bulb temperature in °C \\(T_h\\) is the hot deck air dry-bulb temperature in °C \\(\\dot m_d\\) is the system design air mass flow rate in kg/s \\(\\dot m_c\\) is the cold deck air mass flow rate in kg/s and \\(\\dot m_h\\) is the hot deck air mass flow rate in kg/s."
 },

    "question": "How does the simulation and control process work in the DDCAV model?",

    "question": "What do the variables in the equations represent?",
    "answer": "C_pzone is the specific heat of zone air C_pinlet is the specific heat of inlet air ω_zone is the zone air humidity ratio T_zone is the zone air temperature ω_inlet is the inlet air humidity ratio T_inlet is the inlet air temperature."

    "question": "Question: What is the equation for the terminal unit air mass flow rate?",
    "answer": "Answer: \\dot m = \\min (\\dot m_max \\max (\\dot m_max\\cdot MinAirFlowFrac\\times MinAirFlowTurnDownFrac\\frac\\dot Q_zone\\Delta C_p T))"

 {
    "context": "Context: Definitions of variables used in the simulation equations.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Air System Distribution Terminals ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: List the definitions of the variables used in the equations.",
    "question": "Question: What are the definitions of the variables in the simulation equations?",
    "answer": "Answer: C_pzone is the specific heat of zone air J/kg-K; C_pinlet is the specific heat of terminal unit inlet air J/kg-K; \\omega_zone is the zone air humidity ratio kg/kg; T_zone is the zone air dry-bulb temperature °C; \\omega_inlet is the terminal unit inlet air humidity ratio kg/kg; T_inlet is the terminal unit inlet air dry-bulb temperature °C; \\dot Q_zone is the zone load W; \\dot m is the terminal unit air mass flow rate kg/s; PsyCpAirFnW is the psychrometric function calculating air specific heat given air humidity ratio; MinAirFlowFrac is the user-specified zone minimum air flow fraction; MinAirFlowTurnDownFrac is the user-specified zone minimum air flow turndown fraction; \\dot m_max is the terminal unit maximum air mass flow rate kg/s."
 },

    "question": "What are the equations that the boiler model is based on?",
    "answer": "The boiler model is based on the following equations: OperatingPartLoadRatio = BoilerLoad / BoilerNomCapacity TheoreticalFuelUse = BoilerLoad / NominalThermalEfficiency FuelUsed = TheoreticalFuelUse / BoilerEfficiencyCurveOutput or FuelUsed = BoilerLoad / (NominalThermalEfficiency * BoilerEfficiencyCurveOutput)."

    "context": "Single variable curve types are linear quadratic and cubic.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Boilers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the explain the single independent variable curve types.",
    "question": "What are the single independent variable curve types for boiler efficiency?",
    "answer": "The single independent variable curve types are: Linear: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) Quadratic: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) + C3(PLR)^2 Cubic: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) + C3(PLR)^2 + C4(PLR)^3."
 },
 {
    "context": "Dual independent variable curves include quadratic-linear and biquadratic types.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Boilers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the describe the dual independent variable curve types.",
    "question": "What are the dual independent variable curve types for boiler efficiency?",
    "answer": "The dual independent variable curve types are: QuadraticLinear: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) + C3(PLR)^2 + (C4 + C5(PLR) + C6(PLR)^2)(Twater) Biquadratic: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) + C3(PLR)^2 + C4(Twater) + C5(Twater)^2 + C6(PLR)(Twater) Bicubic: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) + C3(PLR)^2 + C4(Twater) + C5(Twater)^2 + C6(PLR)(Twater) + C7(PLR)^3 + C8(Twater)^3 + C9(PLR)^2(Twater) + C10(PLR)(Twater)^2."

    "question": "How do the generator and absorber function in an absorption chiller?",
    "answer": "The generator and absorber provide the compression operation where low-pressure vapor from the evaporator is absorbed by the liquid solution in the absorber then the liquid is pressurized by a pump and delivered to the generator."

    "question": "How is the part-load ratio (PLR) of the absorption chiller's evaporator calculated?",
    "answer": "PLR is calculated as the actual cooling effect produced by the chiller divided by the maximum cooling effect available."

    "question": "How do you calculate the generator hot water mass flow rate for variable flow chillers?",
    "answer": "The generator hot water mass flow rate is calculated using the equation: \\( \\dotm_generator = \\frac\\dotQ_generatorC_pwater\\Delta T_generator \\)."
 },
 {
    "context": "The outlet temperature of the generator is determined by the inlet temperature and the heat transfer.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the determine the outlet temperature of the generator.",
    "question": "What is the formula for the outlet temperature of the generator?",
    "answer": "The formula for the outlet temperature of the generator is \\( T_generatorout = T_generatorin - \\frac\\dot Q_generator\\dot m_generator\\left( C_p\\\\water \\right) \\)."
 },
 {
    "context": "Definitions of terms used in the equations related to variable flow chillers.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  equation.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the define the terms used in the variable flow chillers equations.",
    "question": "What do the symbols \\(\\dotm_generator\\) \\(\\dotm_generator\max\\) and \\(\\Delta T_generator\\) represent?",
    "answer": "\\(\\dotm_generator\\) is the generator hot water mass flow rate (kg/s) \\(\\dotm_generator\max\\) is the generator design hot water mass flow rate (kg/s) and \\(\\Delta T_generator\\) is the generator design hot water temperature difference (°C)."

 {
    "context": "The indirect absorption chiller model may lead to the deprecation of the existing Chiller:Absorption model.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the discuss the future of the existing Chiller:Absorption model.",
    "question": "Why might the Chiller:Absorption model be deprecated in a future release of EnergyPlus?",
    "answer": "Because the enhanced indirect absorption chiller model can produce similar results to the previous model and offers more flexibility."

 {
    "context": "Description of the components and operation of an indirect absorption chiller.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the describe the operation of an indirect absorption chiller.",
    "question": "How does the indirect absorption chiller operate?",
    "answer": "The chiller's condenser and evaporator are water-to-water heat exchangers. The generator and absorber assembly provides compression. Low-pressure vapor from the evaporator is absorbed by the liquid solution in the absorber. A pump elevates the pressure of the liquid and delivers it to the generator where heat drives off the vapor. The liquid returns to the absorber through a throttling valve."
 },
 {
    "context": "The heat source for the generator in an indirect absorption chiller can be hot water or steam.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the identify the heat sources for the generator in an indirect absorption chiller.",
    "question": "What heat sources can be used for the generator in an indirect absorption chiller?",
    "answer": "The heat sources can be either hot water or steam."
 },

    "context": "Equations for capacity correction factors for evaporator condenser and generator temperatures.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the provide the equations for capacity correction factors.",
    "question": "What are the equations for capacity correction factors for evaporator condenser and generator temperatures?",
    "answer": "The equations are: \\( CAPFT_evaporator = a + b\\left( T_evaporator \\right) + c\\left( T_evaporator \\right)^2 + d\\left( T_evaporator \\right)^3 \\) \\( CAPFT_condenser = e + f\\left( T_condenser \\right) + g\\left( T_condenser \\right)^2 + h\\left( T_condenser \\right)^3 \\) and \\( CAPFT_generator = i + j\\left( T_generator \\right) + k\\left( T_generator \\right)^2 + l\\left( T_generator \\right)^3 \\) (Hot Water only)."

 {
    "context": "Context: Definitions of capacity correction factors and temperature terms are provided.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Define the terms used in the chiller capacity equations.",
    "question": "Question: What are the definitions of the terms used in the chiller capacity equations?",
    "answer": "Answer: CAPFT_evaporator is the capacity correction factor for evaporator temperature CAPFT_condenser is for condenser temperature CAPFT_generator is for generator temperature \(T_evaporator\) is the evaporator outlet water temperature \(T_condenser\) is the condenser inlet water temperature \(T_generator\) is the generator inlet water temperature \(\dot Q_evapmax\) is the maximum chiller capacity and \(\dot Q_evaprated\) is the rated chiller capacity."

    "answer": "Answer: The part-load ratio is the actual cooling effect required divided by the maximum cooling effect available."

    "answer": "GeneratorHIR is the ratio of generator heat input to chiller operating capacity GenfCondT is the heat input modifier based on generator inlet water temperature and GenfEvapT is the heat input modifier based on evaporator outlet water temperature."

 {
    "context": "Description of variables used in the evaporator water mass flow rate formula.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",

    "answer": "\\(\\dot m_evap\\) is the chiller evaporator water mass flow rate (kg/s) \\(\\Delta T_evap\\) is the chiller evaporator water temperature difference (\\(^\\circ\\)C) \\(T_evap\\in\\) is the chiller evaporator inlet water temperature (\\(^\\circ\\)C) \\(T_evap\\SP\\) is the chiller evaporator outlet water setpoint temperature (\\(^\\circ\\)C) \\(C_p\\evap\\) is the specific heat of water entering evaporator (J/kg-\\(^\\circ\\)C)."

    "question": "Question: What factors are considered in calculating the generator outlet node temperature in a hot water loop?",
    "answer": "Answer: The generator heat input mass flow rate of water and the specific heat of water entering the hot water generator are considered."

 {
    "context": "Context: Variable Flow Chillers use different equations for mass flow rate and generator outlet temperature.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  equation.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Provide the equations used in Variable Flow Chillers for mass flow rate and generator outlet temperature.",
    "question": "Question: What are the equations for mass flow rate and generator outlet temperature in Variable Flow Chillers?",
    "answer": "Answer: Mass flow rate: \\( \\dotm_generator = \\frac\\dotQ_generatorC_pwater\\Delta T_generator \\). Generator outlet temperature: \\( T_generatorout = T_generatorin - \\frac\\dotQ_generator\\dotm_generatorC_pwater \\)"

    "answer": "Answer: \\( \\dotm_generator \\) is the generator hot water mass flow rate (kg/s) \\( \\dotm_generator\\max \\) is the generator design hot water mass flow rate (kg/s) and \\( \\Delta T_generator \\) is the generator design hot water temperature difference (°C)."

    "question": "Question: What logic is applied to avoid double-counting parasitic electric load?",
    "answer": "Answer: IF ( HeatElectricPower <= CoolElectricPower ) THEN HeatElectricPower = 0.0 ELSE HeatElectricPower = HeatElectricPower - CoolElectricPower ENDIF"

 {
    "context": "Context: The heating electric input to the chiller is computed using an equation.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",

 },
 {
    "context": "Context: Logic is applied to avoid double-counting the parasitic electric load when the chiller is delivering heating and cooling simultaneously.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Explain the logic to avoid double-counting parasitic electric load.",
    "question": "Question: What logic is applied to avoid double-counting the parasitic electric load?",
    "answer": "Answer: If HeatElectricPower is less than or equal to CoolElectricPower then HeatElectricPower = 0.0; else HeatElectricPower = HeatElectricPower - CoolElectricPower."
 },
 {
    "context": "Context: The total thermal energy and electric power input to the chiller is computed using equations.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",

    "question": "Question: How is the total thermal energy and electric power input to the chiller computed?",
    "answer": "Answer: TotalElectricPower = HeatElectricPower + CoolElectricPower; TotalThermalEnergyInput = HeatThermalEnergyInput + CoolThermalEnergyInput."

    "context": "The temperature rise ratio is calculated using a specific formula involving required and rated temperatures.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the provide the formula for calculating the temperature rise ratio.",
    "question": "What is the formula for the temperature rise ratio?",
    "answer": "TempRiseRatio = (Tcondinrequired - Tcondinrated) / (Tevapoutrequired - Tevapoutrated) - (Tevapout - Tevapoutdesign)"

 {
    "context": "Definitions of various temperature terms used in the chiller model equations.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the list the definitions of the temperature terms used in the chiller model.",
    "question": "What are the definitions of the temperature terms in the chiller model?",
    "answer": "Tcondinrequired: Required entering condenser air or water temperature to maintain rated capacity (°C). Tcondinrated: Rated entering condenser air or water temperature at rated capacity (°C). Tevapoutrequired: Required leaving evaporator water outlet temperature to maintain rated capacity (°C). Tevapoutrated: Rated leaving evaporator water outlet temperature at rated capacity (°C)."
 },

    "answer": "For a water-cooled condenser it's the water temperature returning from the condenser loop. For air- or evap-cooled condensers it's the entering outdoor air dry-bulb or wet-bulb temperature."

    "answer": "PLR is the part-load ratio \\dotQ_evap is the load to be met by the chiller (W) PLR_max is the maximum part-load ratio (specified by the user in the input data file)."
 },
 {
    "context": "The chiller's operation under different load conditions is described.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the explain the chiller's operation under various load conditions.",
    "question": "How does the chiller operate under different load conditions?",
    "answer": "The chiller unloads down to the minimum unloading ratio uses false loading between the minimum unloading ratio and minimum part-load ratio and cycles on and off below the minimum part-load ratio."
 },
 {
    "context": "The chiller cycling ratio is calculated when PLR is less than the minimum part-load ratio.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",

    "question": "How is the chiller cycling ratio calculated when PLR is less than the minimum part-load ratio?",
    "answer": "ChillerCyclingRatio = \\min\\PB\\fracPLRPLR_min1.0"

    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the explain how PLR is adjusted for false loading.",
    "question": "How is the PLR adjusted to account for false loading?",
    "answer": "PLR is reset to the greater of the PLR calculated above and the PLR at the minimum unloading ratio."

    "context": "The amount of false loading on the chiller is calculated.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",

    "question": "How is the amount of false loading on the chiller calculated?",

    "context": "Heat rejection by the chiller condenser is described.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",

    "question": "How is heat rejected by the chiller condenser?",
    "answer": "Heat rejected by the chiller condenser includes the heat transferred in the evaporator plus a portion or all of the compressor electrical energy consumption."
 },
 {
    "context": "Differences between hermetic and open compressors regarding heat rejection.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the describe the differences in heat rejection for hermetic and open compressors.",
    "question": "What is the difference in heat rejection between hermetic and open compressors?",
    "answer": "For electric chillers with hermetic compressors all compressor energy consumption is rejected by the condenser (compressor motor efficiency = eff_motor = 1.0). For chillers with semi-hermetic or open compressors only a portion of the compressor energy use is rejected by the condenser."
 },

    "answer": "ChillerCyclingRatio = min(PLR/PLR_min 1.0)"

    "question": "Question: How is the false loading on the chiller calculated?",

    "question": "Question: How is the chiller compressor power consumption calculated?",

 {
    "context": "Context: The heat rejected by the chiller condenser includes evaporator heat and compressor energy.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Describe the components of heat rejected by the chiller condenser.",
    "question": "Question: What does the heat rejected by the chiller condenser include?",
    "answer": "Answer: The heat rejected includes the heat transferred in the evaporator plus a portion or all of the compressor electrical energy consumption."
 },

    "question": "Question: How is energy rejected in electric chillers with hermetic compressors?",
    "answer": "Answer: All compressor energy consumption is rejected by the condenser with a motor efficiency of 1.0."

    "question": "Question: How is the heat transfer rate for the chiller condenser calculated?",

 {
    "context": "Chilled water part load ratio is calculated using the actual load and design capacity of the chilled water loop.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the describe how to calculate the chilled water part load ratio.",
    "question": "How is the chilled water part load ratio calculated?",
    "answer": "It is calculated using the formula PLR_CHWL = L_CHWL / CAP_CHWL where L_CHWL is the actual load and CAP_CHWL is the design capacity."
 },

    "question": "How is the condenser plant loop water flow fraction obtained?",
    "answer": "It is obtained by feeding the chilled water loop part load ratio through a user-specified curve."

 {
    "context": "A linear curve is expected for the condenser plant loop water flow fraction with coefficients C and D.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the identify the type of curve expected for calculating the condenser plant loop water flow fraction.",
    "question": "What type of curve is expected for calculating the condenser plant loop water flow fraction?",
    "answer": "A linear curve is expected: CWFR = C * PLR_CHWL + D."

    "context": "The actual condenser mass flow request for the chiller is calculated using the design mass flow water flow fraction and evaporator heat transfer rate.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the describe the calculation of the actual condenser mass flow request for the chiller.",
    "question": "How is the actual condenser mass flow request for the chiller calculated?",
    "answer": "It is calculated as m_dot_chiller_condenser = (m_dot_condenser_loop_design * CWFR * Q_dot_chiller_evaporator) / L_CHWL."

    "question": "How does the AirTerminal:SingleDuct:ConstantVolume:Reheat operate?",

 {
    "context": "Explanation of variables in the equations.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Air System Distribution Terminals ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the list the variables used in the equations and their meanings.",
    "question": "What do the variables in the equations represent?",
    "answer": "Cp_zone = Specific heat of zone air J/kg-K; Cp_inlet = Specific heat of terminal unit inlet air J/kg-K; \omega_zone = Zone air humidity ratio kg/kg; T_zone = Zone air dry-bulb temperature °C; \omega_inlet = Terminal unit inlet air humidity ratio kg/kg; T_inlet = Terminal unit inlet air dry-bulb temperature °C; \dot Q_zone = Zone load W; \dot m = Terminal unit air mass flow rate kg/s; PsyCpAirFnW = Psychrometric function; MinAirFlowFrac = User-specified zone minimum air flow fraction; MinAirFlowTurnDownFrac = User-specified zone minimum air flow turndown fraction; \dot m_max = Terminal unit maximum air mass flow rate kg/s."
 },

    "question": "What is the function of the four pipe induction terminal unit?",
    "answer": "The four pipe induction terminal unit is a hybrid air-hydronic unit that supplies centrally conditioned air and local hydronic heating/cooling to a zone inducing a flow of secondary air through a hydronic coil."

    "context": "The text explains when beams need to provide cooling or heating.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Air System Distribution Terminals ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the explain when beams provide cooling or heating.",
    "question": "When do beams provide cooling or heating?",
    "answer": "When \(\dot Q_Zone Required\) is negative beams provide cooling and when it is positive beams provide heating."

    "question": "What are the four inputs that can be autosized in the four pipe beam model?",
    "answer": "1) L is the total length of all beam units serving the zone in m. 2) \\dot V_SADes is the design primary supply air volume flow rate in m³/s. 3) \\dot V_CWDes is the design chilled water volume flow rate in m³/s. 4) \\dot V_HWDes is the design hot water volume flow rate in m³/s."

    "question": "Question: What adjustments are made in central sizing data structures for air system components after the solvers run?",
    "answer": "Answer: After solvers run adjustments are made because usual methods can't account for the four pipe beam sizing. If set to VentilationRequirement the air handler is too small; if set to Sensible it's too large. Adjustments are made to the air loop sizes to match the final primary supply air flow rate size."

    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the identify the equations used in the DDCAV model for energy and mass balance.",
    "question": "What are the energy and mass balance equations used in the DDCAV model?",
    "answer": "1) \\( \\dot Q_zone = \\dot m_c C_pc T_c + \\dot m_h C_phT_h - \\dot m_d C_pz T_z \\) 2) \\( \\dot m_d = \\dot m_c + \\dot m_h \\)"
 },
 {
    "context": "Explanation of terms in the DDCAV equations.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Air System Distribution Terminals ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the define the terms used in the DDCAV model equations.",
    "question": "What do the terms \\(\\dot Q_zone\\) \\(C_pz\\) \\(C_pc\\) \\(C_ph\\) \\(T_z\\) \\(T_c\\) \\(T_h\\) \\(\\dot m_d\\) \\(\\dot m_c\\) and \\(\\dot m_h\\) represent in the DDCAV model?",
    "answer": "\\(\\dot Q_zone\\) is the zone load in W \\(C_pz\\) is the specific heat of zone air in J/kg-K \\(C_pc\\) is the specific heat of cold deck air in J/kg-K \\(C_ph\\) is the specific heat of hot deck air in J/kg-K \\(T_z\\) is the zone air dry-bulb temperature in °C \\(T_c\\) is the cold deck air dry-bulb temperature in °C \\(T_h\\) is the hot deck air dry-bulb temperature in °C \\(\\dot m_d\\) is the system design air mass flow rate in kg/s \\(\\dot m_c\\) is the cold deck air mass flow rate in kg/s and \\(\\dot m_h\\) is the hot deck air mass flow rate in kg/s."
 },

    "question": "How does the simulation and control process work in the DDCAV model?",

    "question": "Question: What are the definitions of the variables in the simulation equations?",
    "answer": "Answer: C_pzone is the specific heat of zone air J/kg-K; C_pinlet is the specific heat of terminal unit inlet air J/kg-K; \\omega_zone is the zone air humidity ratio kg/kg; T_zone is the zone air dry-bulb temperature °C; \\omega_inlet is the terminal unit inlet air humidity ratio kg/kg; T_inlet is the terminal unit inlet air dry-bulb temperature °C; \\dot Q_zone is the zone load W; \\dot m is the terminal unit air mass flow rate kg/s; PsyCpAirFnW is the psychrometric function calculating air specific heat given air humidity ratio; MinAirFlowFrac is the user-specified zone minimum air flow fraction; MinAirFlowTurnDownFrac is the user-specified zone minimum air flow turndown fraction; \\dot m_max is the terminal unit maximum air mass flow rate kg/s."
 },

    "context": "The boiler model is based on three equations.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Boilers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the list the equations used in the boiler model.",
    "question": "What are the equations that the boiler model is based on?",
    "answer": "The boiler model is based on the following equations: OperatingPartLoadRatio = BoilerLoad / BoilerNomCapacity TheoreticalFuelUse = BoilerLoad / NominalThermalEfficiency FuelUsed = TheoreticalFuelUse / BoilerEfficiencyCurveOutput or FuelUsed = BoilerLoad / (NominalThermalEfficiency * BoilerEfficiencyCurveOutput)."

    "context": "Single variable curve types are linear quadratic and cubic.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Boilers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the explain the single independent variable curve types.",
    "question": "What are the single independent variable curve types for boiler efficiency?",
    "answer": "The single independent variable curve types are: Linear: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) Quadratic: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) + C3(PLR)^2 Cubic: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) + C3(PLR)^2 + C4(PLR)^3."
 },
 {
    "context": "Dual independent variable curves include quadratic-linear and biquadratic types.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Boilers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the describe the dual independent variable curve types.",
    "question": "What are the dual independent variable curve types for boiler efficiency?",
    "answer": "The dual independent variable curve types are: QuadraticLinear: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) + C3(PLR)^2 + (C4 + C5(PLR) + C6(PLR)^2)(Twater) Biquadratic: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) + C3(PLR)^2 + C4(Twater) + C5(Twater)^2 + C6(PLR)(Twater) Bicubic: BoilerEfficiencyCurve = C1 + C2(PLR) + C3(PLR)^2 + C4(Twater) + C5(Twater)^2 + C6(PLR)(Twater) + C7(PLR)^3 + C8(Twater)^3 + C9(PLR)^2(Twater) + C10(PLR)(Twater)^2."

    "question": "How do the generator and absorber function in an absorption chiller?",
    "answer": "The generator and absorber provide the compression operation where low-pressure vapor from the evaporator is absorbed by the liquid solution in the absorber then the liquid is pressurized by a pump and delivered to the generator."

    "question": "How is the part-load ratio (PLR) of the absorption chiller's evaporator calculated?",

    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the discuss the future of the existing Chiller:Absorption model.",

 },
 {
    "context": "Description of the components and operation of an indirect absorption chiller.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the describe the operation of an indirect absorption chiller.",
    "question": "How does the indirect absorption chiller operate?",
    "answer": "The chiller's condenser and evaporator are water-to-water heat exchangers. The generator and absorber assembly provides compression. Low-pressure vapor from the evaporator is absorbed by the liquid solution in the absorber. A pump elevates the pressure of the liquid and delivers it to the generator where heat drives off the vapor. The liquid returns to the absorber through a throttling valve."
 },
 {
    "context": "The heat source for the generator in an indirect absorption chiller can be hot water or steam.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the identify the heat sources for the generator in an indirect absorption chiller.",
    "question": "What heat sources can be used for the generator in an indirect absorption chiller?",
    "answer": "The heat sources can be either hot water or steam."
 },

 {
    "context": "Equations for capacity correction factors for evaporator condenser and generator temperatures.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the provide the equations for capacity correction factors.",
    "question": "What are the equations for capacity correction factors for evaporator condenser and generator temperatures?",
    "answer": "The equations are: \\( CAPFT_evaporator = a + b\\left( T_evaporator \\right) + c\\left( T_evaporator \\right)^2 + d\\left( T_evaporator \\right)^3 \\) \\( CAPFT_condenser = e + f\\left( T_condenser \\right) + g\\left( T_condenser \\right)^2 + h\\left( T_condenser \\right)^3 \\) and \\( CAPFT_generator = i + j\\left( T_generator \\right) + k\\left( T_generator \\right)^2 + l\\left( T_generator \\right)^3 \\) (Hot Water only)."

 {
    "context": "Context: The maximum chiller capacity is calculated using rated capacity and capacity correction factors.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Explain how the maximum chiller capacity is calculated.",
    "question": "Question: How is the maximum chiller capacity calculated?",
    "answer": "Answer: The maximum chiller capacity is calculated as \(\dotQ_evapmax = \dotQ_evaprated(CAPFT_evaporator)(CAPFT_condenser)(CAPFT_generator)\)."
 },
 {
    "context": "Context: Definitions of capacity correction factors and temperature terms are provided.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Define the terms used in the chiller capacity equations.",
    "question": "Question: What are the definitions of the terms used in the chiller capacity equations?",
    "answer": "Answer: CAPFT_evaporator is the capacity correction factor for evaporator temperature CAPFT_condenser is for condenser temperature CAPFT_generator is for generator temperature \(T_evaporator\) is the evaporator outlet water temperature \(T_condenser\) is the condenser inlet water temperature \(T_generator\) is the generator inlet water temperature \(\dot Q_evapmax\) is the maximum chiller capacity and \(\dot Q_evaprated\) is the rated chiller capacity."
 },
 {
    "context": "Context: The part-load ratio of the chiller evaporator is defined as the actual cooling effect divided by the maximum cooling effect.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",

    "question": "Question: How is the part-load ratio of a chiller evaporator defined?",
    "answer": "Answer: The part-load ratio is the actual cooling effect required divided by the maximum cooling effect available."

    "question": "Question: What is the equation for the part-load ratio?",
    "answer": "Answer: PLR = \(\frac\dotQ_evap\dotQ_evapmax\)"

    "question": "What happens if the chiller operating part-load ratio is greater than the minimum part-load ratio?",

    "answer": "The chiller will be on for a fraction of the time step equal to CyclingFrac."

    "context": "The equation for CyclingFrac is given.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  equation.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the provide the equation for CyclingFrac.",
    "question": "What is the equation for CyclingFrac?",
    "answer": "CyclingFrac = MIN(1 PLR / PLR_min)"

 {
    "context": "The equation for generator heat input is given.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  equation.",

    "question": "What is the equation for generator heat input (Q_generator)?",
    "answer": "Q_generator = GeneratorHIR(Q_evapmax)(GenfCondT)(GenfEvapT)(CyclingFrac)"

    "answer": "Answer: TCEnt\\(_required\\) is the required entering condenser air or water temperature to maintain rated capacity TCEnt\\(_rated\\) is the rated entering condenser air or water temperature at rated capacity TELv\\(_required\\) is the required leaving evaporator water outlet temperature to maintain rated capacity TELv\\(_rated\\) is the rated leaving evaporator water outlet temperature at rated capacity."

    "question": "Question: How is the heating capacity function of cooling capacity curve normalized?",
    "answer": "Answer: An input of 1.0 represents the nominal cooling capacity and an output of 1.0 represents the full heating capacity. An output of 1.0 should occur when the input is 0.0."

 {
    "context": "Context: Logic to avoid double-counting parasitic electric load when chiller is delivering both heating and cooling.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Explain the logic applied to avoid double-counting parasitic electric load.",
    "question": "Question: What logic is applied to avoid double-counting parasitic electric load?",
    "answer": "Answer: IF ( HeatElectricPower <= CoolElectricPower ) THEN HeatElectricPower = 0.0 ELSE HeatElectricPower = HeatElectricPower - CoolElectricPower ENDIF"

 {
    "context": "Context: The fraction of the time step during which the chiller is operating is computed using an equation.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Explain how to compute the fraction of the time step during which the chiller is operating.",
    "question": "Question: How is the fraction of the time step during which the chiller is operating computed?",
    "answer": "Answer: RunFrac = MIN(1.0 MAX(HPLR CPLRh) / MinPLR)"
 },
 {
    "context": "Context: The heating electric input to the chiller is computed using an equation.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Describe how to compute the heating electric input to the chiller.",
    "question": "Question: How is the heating electric input to the chiller computed?",
    "answer": "Answer: HeatElectricPower = NomCoolCap * HeatCoolCapRatio * HEIR * RunFrac"
 },
 {
    "context": "Context: Logic is applied to avoid double-counting the parasitic electric load when the chiller is delivering heating and cooling simultaneously.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Explain the logic to avoid double-counting parasitic electric load.",
    "question": "Question: What logic is applied to avoid double-counting the parasitic electric load?",
    "answer": "Answer: If HeatElectricPower is less than or equal to CoolElectricPower then HeatElectricPower = 0.0; else HeatElectricPower = HeatElectricPower - CoolElectricPower."
 },
 {
    "context": "Context: The total thermal energy and electric power input to the chiller is computed using equations.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the instruction: Describe how to compute the total thermal energy and electric power input to the chiller.",
    "question": "Question: How is the total thermal energy and electric power input to the chiller computed?",
    "answer": "Answer: TotalElectricPower = HeatElectricPower + CoolElectricPower; TotalThermalEnergyInput = HeatThermalEnergyInput + CoolThermalEnergyInput."
 },

 {
    "context": "Error handling for zero condenser flow in water-cooled condensers.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the handle zero condenser flow error for water-cooled condensers.",
    "question": "What happens if the condenser flow is zero in a water-cooled condenser?",
    "answer": "CALL ShowSevereError(`CalcConstCOPChillerModel: Condenser flow = 0 for CONST COP Chiller = //~ \\& ~~~~~~ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~TRIM(ConstCOPChiller(ChillNum)\\%Name)); CALL ShowFatalError(`Program Terminates due to previous error condition.)"

    "context": "The temperature rise ratio is calculated using a specific formula involving required and rated temperatures.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the provide the formula for calculating the temperature rise ratio.",
    "question": "What is the formula for the temperature rise ratio?",
    "answer": "TempRiseRatio = (Tcondinrequired - Tcondinrated) / (Tevapoutrequired - Tevapoutrated) - (Tevapout - Tevapoutdesign)"

 {
    "context": "Definitions of various temperature terms used in the chiller model equations.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the list the definitions of the temperature terms used in the chiller model.",
    "question": "What are the definitions of the temperature terms in the chiller model?",
    "answer": "Tcondinrequired: Required entering condenser air or water temperature to maintain rated capacity (°C). Tcondinrated: Rated entering condenser air or water temperature at rated capacity (°C). Tevapoutrequired: Required leaving evaporator water outlet temperature to maintain rated capacity (°C). Tevapoutrated: Rated leaving evaporator water outlet temperature at rated capacity (°C)."
 },

    "answer": "The part-load ratio is the actual cooling load divided by the chiller's available cooling capacity."

 {
    "context": "Heat rejection by the chiller condenser is described.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the explain how heat is rejected by the chiller condenser.",
    "question": "How is heat rejected by the chiller condenser?",
    "answer": "Heat rejected by the chiller condenser includes the heat transferred in the evaporator plus a portion or all of the compressor electrical energy consumption."
 },
 {
    "context": "Differences between hermetic and open compressors regarding heat rejection.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the describe the differences in heat rejection for hermetic and open compressors.",
    "question": "What is the difference in heat rejection between hermetic and open compressors?",
    "answer": "For electric chillers with hermetic compressors all compressor energy consumption is rejected by the condenser (compressor motor efficiency = eff_motor = 1.0). For chillers with semi-hermetic or open compressors only a portion of the compressor energy use is rejected by the condenser."
 },

    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the explain how the chiller cycling ratio is determined.",
    "question": "What is the formula for calculating the chiller cycling ratio?",
    "answer": "ChillerCyclingRatio = min(PLR/PLR_min 1.0)"
 },
 {
    "context": "To account for chiller electric power consumption when PLR is less than the minimum unloading ratio the PLR is reset.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the describe the adjustment made to the PLR under certain conditions.",
    "question": "How is the PLR adjusted when it is less than the minimum unloading ratio?",
    "answer": "PLR is reset to the greater of the calculated PLR and the PLR at the minimum unloading ratio."
 },

    "question": "What does the revised PLR account for?",
    "answer": "The revised PLR accounts for false loading such as hot gas bypass."

 {
    "context": "The amount of false loading on the chiller is calculated and reported as an output variable.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the provide the formula for calculating false loading.",
    "question": "What is the equation used to calculate the amount of false loading on the chiller?",
    "answer": "Q_falseloading = (Q_avail)(PLR)(ChillerCyclingRatio) - Q_evap"
 },

    "question": "What is the formula for calculating the chiller compressor's electrical power consumption?",
    "answer": "P_chiller = (Q_avail)(1/COP_ref)(ChillerEIRFTemp)(ChillerEIRFPLR)(ChillerCyclingRatio)"

 {
    "context": "The IPLV formula is provided.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the provide the formula for calculating IPLV.",
    "question": "What is the formula for calculating IPLV?",
    "answer": "IPLV = (0.01A) + (0.42B) + (0.45C) + (0.12D)"
 },
 {
    "context": "The components of the IPLV formula are defined.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the define the components of the IPLV formula.",
    "question": "What are the components of the IPLV formula?",
    "answer": "A is the EER or COP at 100% capacity B is the EER or COP at 75% capacity C is the EER or COP at 50% capacity D is the EER or COP at 25% capacity."

 {
    "context": "Chilled water part load ratio is calculated using the actual load and design capacity of the chilled water loop.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the describe how to calculate the chilled water part load ratio.",
    "question": "How is the chilled water part load ratio calculated?",
    "answer": "It is calculated using the formula PLR_CHWL = L_CHWL / CAP_CHWL where L_CHWL is the actual load and CAP_CHWL is the design capacity."

    "question": "What type of curve is expected for calculating the condenser plant loop water flow fraction?",
    "answer": "A linear curve is expected: CWFR = C * PLR_CHWL + D."

    "context": "The actual condenser mass flow request for the chiller is calculated using the design mass flow water flow fraction and evaporator heat transfer rate.; From EnergyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Simulation Models -- Encyclopedic Reference -> Section: Chillers ->  text.",
    "instruction": "Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the describe the calculation of the actual condenser mass flow request for the chiller.",
    "question": "How is the actual condenser mass flow request for the chiller calculated?",
    "answer": "It is calculated as m_dot_chiller_condenser = (m_dot_condenser_loop_design * CWFR * Q_dot_chiller_evaporator) / L_CHWL."
